sections.heading: Overview
sections.content:
PyMongo is a Python package that you can use to connect
to and communicate with MongoDB. This guide shows you how to create an
application that uses PyMongo to connect to a MongoDB cluster hosted on
MongoDB Atlas.

sections.heading: Tip
sections.content:
MongoDB Atlas is a fully managed cloud database service that hosts your MongoDB
deployments. You can create your own free (no credit card required) MongoDB Atlas
deployment by following the steps in this guide.
Follow this guide to connect a sample Python application to a MongoDB Atlas
deployment. If you prefer to connect to MongoDB using a different driver or
programming language, see our list of official drivers .

subsections.heading: Alternative Installation Methods
subsections.content:
The following steps show you how to install PyMongo by using pip . To install
PyMongo from source, see Install from Source in the API documentation.

subsections.heading: Install dependencies
subsections.content:
Ensure you have the following dependencies installed
in your development environment:
- Python3 version 3.8 or later
- pip
- dnspython

sections.heading: Create a MongoDB Deployment
sections.content:
You can create a free-tier MongoDB deployment on MongoDB Atlas
to store and manage your data. MongoDB Atlas hosts and manages
your MongoDB database in the cloud.

subsections.heading: Create a free MongoDB deployment on Atlas
subsections.content:
Complete the Get Started with Atlas guide to set up a new Atlas account and load sample data into a new free
tier MongoDB deployment.

subsections.heading: Save your credentials
subsections.content:
After you create your database user, save that user's
username and password to a safe location for use in an upcoming step.
After you complete these steps, you have a new free tier MongoDB
deployment on Atlas, database user credentials, and sample data loaded
in your database.

sections.heading: Create a Connection String
sections.content:
You can connect to your MongoDB deployment by providing a connection URI , also called a connection string , which
instructs the driver on how to connect to a MongoDB deployment
and how to behave while connected.
The connection string includes the hostname or IP address and
port of your deployment, the authentication mechanism, user credentials
when applicable, and connection options.
To connect to an instance or deployment not hosted on Atlas, see Choose a Connection Target .

subsections.heading: Find your MongoDB Atlas connection string
subsections.content:
To retrieve your connection string for the deployment that
you created in the previous step ,
log into your Atlas account and navigate to the Database section and click the Connect button
for your new deployment.
Proceed to the Connect your application section and select
"Python" from the Driver selection menu and the version
that best matches the version you installed from the Version selection menu.
Select the Password (SCRAM) authentication mechanism.
Deselect the Include full driver code example option to view
the connection string.

subsections.content:

subsections.heading: Update the placeholders
subsections.content:
Paste this connection string into a file in your preferred text editor
and replace the <username> and <password> placeholders with
your database user's username and password.
Save this file to a safe location for use in the next step.
After completing these steps, you have a connection string that
contains your database username and password.

subsections.heading: Create your PyMongo application
subsections.content:
Copy and paste the following code into the quickstart.py file in your application.
Select the Synchronous or Asynchronous tab to see the
corresponding code:
code_blocks: from pymongo import MongoClient uri = "<connection string URI>" client = MongoClient(uri) try : database = client.get_database( "sample_mflix" ) movies = database.get_collection( "movies" ) # Query for a movie that has the title 'Back to the Future' query = { "title" : "Back to the Future" } movie = movies.find_one(query) print (movie) client.close() except Exception as e: raise Exception( "Unable to find the document due to the following error: " , e)

import asyncio from pymongo import AsyncMongoClient async def main () : uri = "<connection string URI>" client = AsyncMongoClient(uri) try : database = client.get_database( "sample_mflix" ) movies = database.get_collection( "movies" ) # Query for a movie that has the title 'Back to the Future' query = { "title" : "Back to the Future" } movie = await movies.find_one(query) print (movie) await client.close() except Exception as e: raise Exception( "Unable to find the document due to the following error: " , e) # Run the async function asyncio.run(main())

subsections.heading: Assign the connection string
subsections.content:
Replace the <connection string URI> placeholder with the
connection string that you copied from the Create a Connection String step of this guide.

sections.heading: Tip
sections.content:
If you encounter an error or see no output, check whether you specified the
proper connection string, and that you loaded the
sample data.
After you complete these steps, you have a working application that
uses the driver to connect to your MongoDB deployment, runs a query on
the sample data, and prints out the result.

sections.heading: Next Steps
sections.content:
Congratulations on completing the tutorial!
In this tutorial, you created a Python application that
connects to a MongoDB deployment hosted on MongoDB Atlas
and retrieves a document that matches a query.
Learn more about PyMongo from the following resources:
- Learn how to insert documents in the Insert Documents section.
- Learn how to find documents in the Query section.
- Learn how to update documents in the Update Documents section.
- Learn how to delete documents in the Delete Documents section.
